instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_PWM: What is BKLT_PWM? BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKLT_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LP8545: What is LP8545? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight - no <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have this board that was sent in from another shop. It appears as if there was liquid damage but not in the area of the LCD connector or the <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP>.
I tested with another display I have and that one also had no backlight and I could see the flashing folder as well.
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> measured 3.11v but when I measured <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR>(<SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>) I got 0.008v.

On Pin 40 of the LCD Connector I was getting around 24v on backlight.

I even ran a wire from pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> to Pin1 of <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and when I measured <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> they both measured 0v which looks like something is pulling those down.

Should I replace the <CHIP>LP8545</CHIP> or should I ultrasonic the board to make sure the <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> chip is not the issue?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight - no <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance to GND on PWM line? Remove <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> to check which side the short is.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight - no <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Resistance to ground on PWM is 98kohms.

<RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> is not shorted to ground. In diode mode <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> is 0.44v.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight - no <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You can try to replace the 8545 and if that does not help remove <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and connect to 3V directly. I assume you did a few PRAM resets and such?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight - no <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I did the first two things you said to do and neither worked so I did a PRAM Reset and the backlight appeared and everything is working fine.

Thanks duke!
